SEARCH
Package org.loudouncodes.jkarel

Class Robot

java.lang.Object
org.loudouncodes.jkarel.Item
org.loudouncodes.jkarel.Robot
Direct Known Subclasses:
AlphaBot
public class Robot extends Item
One of the main concepts implemented by this Library. In the curriculum that uses this library, we will create robots and move them around the arena. We'll also 'subclass' robots, teaching them how to do new things. As defined by the original Karel the Robot curriculum, robots can only:
  • Know what direction they are facing
  • Know if they are next to a wall (and where it is)
  • Move Forward
  • Turn Left
  • Drop 'Beepers'
  • Pick up 'Beepers'
  • Know if they are currently 'on top of' a beeper
Anything other than that, you will teach it.

  • Field Details

    • direction

      protected Direction direction
      The current direction the robot is facing. This is protected so that in a future OO design class, students can learn a better implementation of turnRight().

  • Constructor Details

    • Robot

      public Robot()
      Constructs a robot at [1, 1], facing east, with 0 beepers.

    • Robot

      public Robot(int x, int y, Direction dir, int beepers)
      Constructs a robot at a location you specify, facing the direction you specify, with the number of beepers you specify. Design note - this constructor does too much.
      Parameters:
      x - the x location where this robot is constructed.
      y - the y location where this robot is constructed.
      dir - the Direction this robot is facing when constructed.
      beepers - . The number of beepers this robot has when constructed.

  • Method Details

    • initializeIcons

      protected void initializeIcons()
      Subclasses that know what they are doing can override this method in order to change the way robots draw themselves in the arena. return a hashmap with Directions as the key and icons as the value.

    • getDirection

      public Direction getDirection()
      Returns the direction this robot is facing.
      Returns:
      an enum indicating the direction this robot is facing.

    • getBeepers

      public int getBeepers()
      Returns the number of beepers this Robot is currently holding.
      Returns:
      the number of beepers this Robot is currently holding.

    • move

      public void move()
      Moves the robot one step forward (in the direction it is facing)

    • backUp

      protected void backUp()
      Moves the robot one step backward (from the direction it is facing)

    • turnLeft

      public void turnLeft()
      Turns the Robot 90 degrees to the left.

    • putBeeper

      public void putBeeper()
      Drops a single beeper at the current location. The number of beepers this robot is holding is decreased by 1. If there are no beepers, this method will log an error and stop the program.

    • setColor

      public void setColor(Color c)

    • getColor

      public Color getColor()

    • pickBeeper

      public void pickBeeper()
      Picks a beeper up from the current location and adds it to the Robot's beeper inventory. If there are no beepers present, this method will log an error and stop the program.

    • hasBeepers

      public boolean hasBeepers()
      returns true if this robot has beepers in its inventory.
      Returns:
      true if this robot has beepers in its inventory, false otherwise.

    • frontIsClear

      public boolean frontIsClear()
      Returns:
      boolean is the front clear of any walls?

      public boolean rightIsClear()
      Returns:
      boolean is the right clear of any walls?

      public boolean backIsClear()
      Returns:
      boolean is the back clear of any walls?

    • nextToABeeper

      public boolean nextToABeeper()
      Returns:
      boolean am I next to (on top of) any beepers?

    • nextToARobot

      public boolean nextToARobot()
      Returns:
      boolean am I next to (on top of) any robots?

      Returns:
      boolean am I facing West?

    • explode

      public void explode()
      Removes this robot from the current arena. not as cool as it sounds. It needs an explosion or something.

    • render

      public void render(Graphics g, int x, int y)
      You will never need to call this method unless you are working inside the jkarel library itself. The library calls this method when the robot needs to draw itself on the screen. In advanced uses of this library, you can subclass Robot and override this method, making a robot that can draw something other than the default image.
      Specified by:
      render in class Item
      Parameters:
      g - the Graphics context to draw into
      x - the x location where the robot should draw itself
      y - the y location where the robot should draw itself

    • nextToRobot

      public boolean nextToRobot(Robot other)
      Returns true if we are next to a robot, false otherwise. Note that 'next to' really means 'on top of' because of the way Karel graphics look and work. This is like two robots standing next to each other on a streetcorner.
      Parameters:
      other - the other robot we are testing to see if we are next to.
      Returns:
      true if we are next to a robot, false otherwise.
